AI 143622: Correctly startListening() for widget updates when first boot completes.
During the first boot upgrade, LauncherProvider will deleteHost() to clear out any old appWidgetId bindings.  During the first boot, Launcher calls AppWidgetHost.startListening() to watch for widget updates.  It also calls loadUserItems(), which loads data from LauncherProvider, triggering the database creation and deleteHost() call.  Because deleteHost() removes any existing callbacks, any future widget updates are dropped on the floor.  (This can currently be solved by rebooting, because there isn't an upgrade on subsequent boots.)
This bug was particularly evident on vfpioneer-userdebug builds, as there aren't any configuration changes that cause Launcher to be destroyed and recreated.  (When destroyed and recreated, we startListening() again, and LauncherProvider doesn't call deleteHost().)
To handle this special case, Launcher creates a ContentObserver pointing at a specific URI, which the LauncherProvider notifies when the AppWidgetHost is reset through deleteHost(), allowing Launcher to correctly startListening() again.

Fixes #1596240. Optimize invalidate/draw passes by marking opaque views and avoiding drawing them. Whenever a View requests an invalidate its parent check whether the view is opaque or not. When the view is not opaque, the framework behaves as it used to. However, when a view is opaque, the parent marks itself as being dirty because of an opaque view. Its parent then does the same, and so on. When the framework then starts drawing the views, it does not draw views marked as dirty opaque. If a view is dirty opaque and receives an invalidate request from a non-opaque view, it then clears the dirty opaque flag and behaves as before.

Fix DesktopItemsLoader writes directly into mDesktopItems while reading data.

DesktopItemsLoader reads directly into mDesktopItems, etc., which isn't safe
threading practice.  These aren't synchronized at all, and it's combining with
other bugs to cause the race condition leading to disappearing launcher icons.

Log if launcher threads don't exit before the timeout.

This is the fundamental cause of the disappearing launcher icons bug.

Separate mRunning handling from the DesktopItemsLoader logic.

This ensures that we always set mRunning to false if we return before
the end of the function, and prepares for other upcoming fixes.

Fix possible race condition stopping mDesktopLoaderThread.

mRunning is set inside the thread, after it's already running.  It's
possible that the thread might be held up by other activity, and not
get to do anything for a while.  We could come back into loadUserItems
before mRunning is set; it wouldn't think the thread is running, so
it wouldn't try to stop it, leading to two DesktopLoaderThreads running.

Change 'running' to '!finished', and consider the object not finished
as soon as it's created.  This requires that this object be only used
once, which it is.  It also requires that the object's thread be created
if it's created at all, or mFinished will never be set.

It would be a bit cleaner to set mRunning to true as soon as the Thread
is created, but there's no override in Runnable to do that; we'd need to
rearchitect this a bit to make DesktopItemsLoader itself be the thread,
rather than a runnable held by mDesktopLoaderThread.  It's not worth the
bigger change against upstream to do this.

Fix updateShortcutLabels doesn't abort.

When DesktopItemsLoader is stopping, updateShortcutLabels should stop

Don't allow launcher thread joins to timeout.

This was the fundamental cause of launcher icons disappearing: ths code
blindly assumed that thread joins would never time out, and the exception
was simply thrown away, so the behavior when it did was never tested.

Some misbehaviors when this was happening have been fixed, but this really
shouldn't be allowed to happen.  If the thread isn't dying, then we really
should allow the FC dialog to pop up, and not just continue on and hope
everything works out.

Fix a launcher deadlock.

loadApplications and stopAndWaitForApplicationsLoader are synchronized,
and ApplicationsLoader::run synchronizes with LauncherModel, causing
a deadlock.

(The problem was exposed by removing the timeout from the thread joins.
Previously, it would deadlock for five seconds, then time out and march
on blindly.  This means that compared to CM5.0.7 before the disappearing
icons fix, this should fix some random 5-second stalls in the launcher.)

Remove the synchronize.  Even if mStopped is set to true after the conditional,
we still have, in fact, successfully loaded applications, so it's perfectly
valid to set mApplicationsLoaded.  The only caveat is that other threads can
only safely set mApplicationsLoaded back to false if the thread isn't running.

This means that abortLoaders shouldn't be setting mApplicationsLoaded = false,
because it doesn't end the thread; it just asynchronously asks the thread to
exit and then continues without waiting.  Leave it to the thread, when it
finally exits, to set mApplicationsLoaded correctly.

Note that loadApplications also sets mApplicationsLoaded = false.  That's correct
(though probably redundant); the thread is never running here (we just called
stopAndWaitForApplicationsLoader), and this is explicitly clearing the app cache
to reload it.

This has a side-effect: previously, abortLoaders had the unobvious side-effect
of clearing the app cache (clearing mApplicationsLoaded).  That no longer happens.
This function is only used by Launcher on shutdown anyway.

First try to create a fallback for the DragLayer memory issues

When users longpress anything, the DragLayer tries to create the drawing cache of that View,
and create a BitMap copy of the drawing cache to move it around the screen.
Under low memory conditions, the drawing cache cannot be generated by android, so it throws nasty NPEs
while trying to access that drawing cache.

I've created a fallback to draw just roundRects when the cache cannot be generated.
